title: Casimir Gide
text:
Casimir Gide (4 July 1804 – 18 February 1868) was a 19th-century French composer, bookseller as well as prints and maps editor.
Biography.
The son of the Parisian bookseller Theophile Etienne Gide (1768–1837), to whom he would succeed, and of a singer in the chapel of the king, he studied <a href="harmony">harmony</a> and <a href="musical%20composition">musical composition</a> at the <a href="Conservatoire%20de%20Paris">Conservatoire de Paris</a>. On 4 February 1833, he received the bookseller patent from the Maison Gide fils. He was a major printer of <a href="Lithography">lithographs</a> and financed the publication of six volumes, among them nineteen of the "Voyages pittoresques et romantiques dans l'ancienne France" by <a href="Charles%20Nodier">Charles Nodier</a> and <a href="Justin%20Taylor">Justin Taylor</a>. In 1854, he was one of the first to launch the trend of salon operettas and artistic evenings.
Works.
He wrote <a href="incidental%20music">incidental music</a>, <a href="ballet">ballet</a>s and <a href="opera">opera</a>s.
